name: Natural Science
description: Natural Science is the branch of knowledge that deals with the natural or physical world, in contrast to the social sciences and human sciences.

children.name: Mathematics
children.description: The study of numbers (quantity) and other topics including structure, space, and change.

children.name: Statistics
children.description: A branch of applied mathematics concerned with the collection and interpretation of quantitative data and the use of probability theory to estimate population parameters.

children.name: Econometrics
children.description: Econometrics is the application of mathematics and statistics to the study of economic and financial data.

children.name: Statistical Physics
children.description: Statistical Physics is a branch of physics that uses probability theory and statistics to solve physical problems that usually involve systems composed of a large number of units. Its main purpose is to study the properties of a system from the statistical behaviour of its components.

children.name: Medical Biometry
children.description: Medical Biometry is the branch of science that deals with the statistical analysis of numerical data relating to humans, especially concerning genetic relationships or medical conditions.

children.name: Applied Mathematics
children.description: The application of mathematics to specific problems in science, typically by the formulation and analysis of mathematical models.

children.name: Nonlinear Dynamics
children.description: Nonlinear Dynamics is the branch of Physics that studies systems governed by equations more complex than the linear, aX+b form. Nonlinear systems, such as the weather or neurons, often appear chaotic, unpredictable or counterintuitive, and yet their behaviour is not random.

children.name: Pure Mathematics
children.description: The study of abstract mathematical concepts.

children.name: Mathematical Psychology
children.description: Mathematical Psychology is an approach to psychological research that is based on mathematical modeling of perceptual, thought, cognitive and motor processes, and on the establishment of law-like rules that relate quantifiable stimulus characteristics with quantifiable behavior.

children.name: Population Dynamics
children.description: Population Dynamics is the study of how and why populations change in size and structure over time. Important factors in population dynamics include rates of reproduction, death and migration.

children.name: Life Science
children.description: Life Science is the study of all of the divisions of the natural sciences dealing with the various aspects of the phenomena of life and vital processes.

children.name: Fisheries Science
children.description: Fisheries Science is the academic discipline of managing and understanding fisheries. It is a multidisciplinary science, which draws on the disciplines of limnology, oceanography, freshwater biology, marine biology, conservation, ecology, population dynamics, economics and management to attempt to provide an integrated picture of fisheries. [Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisheries_science, AL 23.5.18]

children.name: Aquaculture
children.description: Aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms in both coastal and inland areas involving interventions in the rearing process to enhance production.[Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) http://www.fao.org/aquaculture/en/, AL 23.5.18]

children.name: Medicine
children.description: Medicine is the science or practice of the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease.

children.name: Cardiology
children.description: The branch of medicine dealing with the heart and its diseases.

children.name: Endocrinology
children.description: Endocrinology is a branch of medicine concerned with the structure, function, and disorders of the endocrine glands.

children.name: Diabetology
children.description: Diabetology is a branch of medicine dealing with the study and treatment of diabetes mellitus.

children.name: Oncology
children.description: The study of tumors encompassing the physical, chemical, and biologic properties.

children.name: Radiation Oncology
children.description: Radiation Oncology is the study of the effects of ionizing radiation for treatment of tumors.

children.name: Psychiatry
children.description: The medical specialty that deals with the medical management of mental disorders.

children.name: Psychosomatic Medicine
children.description: A branch of medicine concerned with the relationship between emotion and body function.

children.name: Critical Care Medicine
children.description: The multidisciplinary that cares for patients with acute, life-threatening illness or injury.

children.name: Anaesthesiology
children.description: Anaesthesia and anaesthetics.

children.name: Geriatric Medicine
children.description: The branch of medicine dealing with the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of disease in older people, and the problems specific to aging.

children.name: Forensic Medicine
children.description: The application of medical knowledge to questions of law; research, reports and testimony in court by experts in medical science to assist in determining a legal question.

children.name: Traditional Medicine
children.description: Medical therapies that fall beyond the scope of conventional medicine but may be used alongside it in the treatment of disease and ill health.

children.name: Radiology
children.description: The branch of medical science dealing with the medical use of X-rays or other penetrating radiation.

children.name: Nuclear Medicine
children.description: Nuclear Medicine is the branch of medicine that uses radioactive materials either to image a patient's body or to destroy diseased cells.

children.name: Reproductive Health
children.description: Reproductive Health is a research area that addresses the reproductive processes, functions and system at all stages of life.

children.name: Public Health
children.description: The science and practice of protecting and improving the health of a community, as by preventive medicine, health education, control of communicable diseases, application of sanitary measures, and monitoring of environmental hazards.

children.name: Social Medicine
children.description: Social Medicine is a branch of science concerned with social and economic aspects of health, disease, and medical care.

children.name: Community Care
children.description: Community Care research is concerned with services that are intended to help people who need care and support to live with dignity and independence in the community and to avoid social isolation. The services are aimed at the elderly and those who have mental illness, learning disability and physical disability. The main aim in providing community care services is to enable people to remain living in their own homes and to retain as much independence as possible, avoiding social isolation.

children.name: Health Services Research
children.description: A multidisciplinary field of inquiry that examines the costs, quality, accessibility, delivery, organization, financing, and outcomes of health care services.

children.name: Global Health
children.description: Global health is field of study concerned with the health of populations in a global context; this includes worldwide health improvement (including mental health), reduction of disparities, and protection against global threats that disregard national borders. Global health can be measured as a function of various global diseases and their prevalence in the world and threat to decrease life in the present day.

children.name: Epidemiology
children.description: The study of the causes, incidence and distribution of disease in the population and its application for prevention or control.

children.name: Population Dynamics
children.description: Population Dynamics is the study of how and why populations change in size and structure over time. Important factors in population dynamics include rates of reproduction, death and migration.

children.name: Medical Biometry
children.description: Medical Biometry is the branch of science that deals with the statistical analysis of numerical data relating to humans, especially concerning genetic relationships or medical conditions.

children.name: Occupational Medicine
children.description: This branch of medicine is concerned with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of injuries and illnesses that occur at the workplace or as a result of toxic exposures, stress, or accidents at the workplace. Occupational medicine encompasses issues such as industrial hygiene, safety, pollution control, ergonomics, industrial and agricultural toxicology, disability evaluation, physical rehabilitation, industrial psychology and emergency medicine. (BioTech Life Science Dictionary)

children.name: Gynecology
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women.

children.name: Surgery
children.description: The branch of medical science that treats disease or injury by operative procedures.

children.name: Orthopedic Surgery
children.description: Orthopedic Surgery is the branch of surgery broadly concerned with the skeletal system (bones and joints).

children.name: Cardiothoracic Surgery
children.description: Cariothoracic Surgery is the field of medicine involved in surgical treatment of organs inside the thorax (the chest)â€”generally treatment of conditions of the heart (heart disease) and lungs (lung disease).

children.name: Vascular Surgery
children.description: A surgical specialty that focuses on diagnosis and management of disorders of the arterial, venous and lymphatic systems, other than the intracranial vessels and the heart.

children.name: Oral Surgery
children.description: Surgical procedures for treating diseases and disorders of the oral cavity.

children.name: Dentistry
children.description: The study, diagnosis, prevention and treatments of disorders of the oral cavity, maxillofacial area and adjacent structures.

children.name: Medical Psychology
children.description: Medical Psychology is the application of Clinical Psychology to medicine-specific issues. It also includes the application of psychological principles to the practice of medicine, including the integration of somatic and psychotherapeutic modalities into the management of illnesses and disorders.

children.name: Nephrology
children.description: A branch of medicine concerned with the development, anatomy, function, and dysfunction of the kidney.

children.name: Ophthalmology
children.description: A medical specialty concerned with the structure and function of the eye and the medical and surgical treatment of its defects and diseases.

children.name: Musculoskeletal Medicine
children.description: Musculoskeletal Medicine is the diagnosis and treatment of problems arising from the musculoskeletal system. This includes injuries and diseases affecting the muscles, bones and joints of the limbs and spine.

children.name: Orthopedic Surgery
children.description: Orthopedic Surgery is the branch of surgery broadly concerned with the skeletal system (bones and joints).

children.name: Rheumatology
children.description: A medical specialty that deals with diagnosis and treatment of diseases and disorders of the connective tissues.

children.name: Medical Toxicology
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis, management and prevention of poisoning and other adverse health effects caused by medications, occupational and environmental toxins, and biological agents.

children.name: Personalized Medicine
children.description: An approach to medicine whereby decisions, practices and are tailored to the individual patient based on their predicted response or risk of disease.

children.name: Human Genetics
children.description: The study of inheritance in human beings.

children.name: Pediatrics
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the medical care of infants, children and adolescents.

children.name: Pharmacy
children.description: Pharmacy is the medical area concerned with the preparation and dispensing of medicinal drugs.

children.name: Regenerative Medicine
children.description: The branch of medicine that involves the laboratory growth of functional tissues and organs and their use to regenerate or replace tissues and organs in the body that are damaged by diseases or cannot be healed. Examples include the transplantation of in vitro developed tissues, cell therapies, and stimulation of regeneration by biological substances.

children.name: Infectious Disease Medicine
children.description: Infectious Disease Medicine is a branch of internal medicine concerned with the diagnosis and treatment of infectious diseases.

children.name: Dermatology
children.description: The branch of medicine focused on the study of the skin, and responsible for the medical management of its associated diseases.

children.name: Primary Health Care
children.description: Primary Health Care is a whole-of-society approach to health and well-being centred on the needs and preferences of individuals, families and communities.  It addresses the broader determinants of health and focuses on the comprehensive and interrelated aspects of physical, mental and social health and wellbeing.

children.name: Gender Medicine
children.description: The study of the biological and physiological differences between males and females and how they effect differences in disease presentation and management.

children.name: Medical Virology
children.description: Medical Virology is the study of the diagnosis and management of infectious diseases from a clinical and laboratory perspective, with particular interest in infection control, medical microbiology and public health.

children.name: Pharmacology
children.description: The study of pharmacologic agents. This includes the preparation, compounding, and dispensing of drugs, as well as the characteristics and properties of drugs, their effects on the body, and how they are metabolized and eliminated from the body.

children.name: Toxicology
children.description: Toxicology is the branch of pharmacology that deals with the nature and effects and treatments of poisons.

children.name: Toxicogenomics
children.description: Toxicogenomics is a new scientific field that elucidates how the entire genome is involved in biological responses of organisms exposed to environmental toxicants/stressors. Toxicogenomics combines information from studies of genomic-scale mRNA profiling (by microarray analysis), cell-wide or tissue-wide protein profiling (proteomics), genetic susceptibility, and computational models to understand the roles of gene-environment interactions in disease. (from National Center for Toxicogenomics homepage)

children.name: Medical Toxicology
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis, management and prevention of poisoning and other adverse health effects caused by medications, occupational and environmental toxins, and biological agents.

children.name: Pharmacogenomics
children.description: The influence of genotype on drug response, for example by correlating gene expression or single-nucleotide polymorphisms with drug efficacy or toxicity.

children.name: Neurology
children.description: A branch of medicine concerned with the development, anatomy, function, and dysfunction of the nervous system.

children.name: Gastroenterology
children.description: The branch of medicine that focuses on diagnosis and treatment of conditions affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

children.name: Physiology
children.description: The functions of living organisms and their constituent parts.

children.name: Neurophysiology
children.description: A branch of neuroscience concerned with the physiology of the nervous system.

children.name: Animal Physiology
children.description: Animal Physiology is the study of the normal processes and metabolic functions of animal organisms.

children.name: Microbial Physiology
children.description: The metabolism of microbial life forms.

children.name: Electrophysiology
children.description: That branch of physiology that is concerned with the electric phenomena associated with living bodies and involved in their functional activity.

children.name: Clinical Chemistry
children.description: The department responsible for performing chemical and enzymatic analyses of body fluids and tissues. (from Handbook of Medical Informatics)

children.name: Pathobiochemistry
children.description: Pathobiochemistry is an intersiciplinary research area related to both biochemistry and pathology. Research focuses on diseases as a disruption of the ordinary biochemical processes of an organism.

children.name: Veterinary Medicine
children.description: Topic concerning the branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disease, disorder and injury in animals.

children.name: Clinical Veterinary Medicine
children.description: Clinical Veterinary Medicine deals with the observation, diagnosis and treatment of illness, disease or damage through direct interaction with non-human patients.

children.name: Urology
children.description: The medical specialty concerned with the study, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the genitourinary tract.

children.name: Medical Physics
children.description: Medical Physics is the application of physics to healthcare; using physics for patient imaging, measurement and treatment.

children.name: Radiobiology
children.description: The study of the mechanisms and biological effects of ionizing radiation, including repair processes.

children.name: Radiation Oncology
children.description: Radiation Oncology is the study of the effects of ionizing radiation for treatment of tumors.

children.name: Tropical Medicine
children.description: Health problems that are prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions.

children.name: Translational Medicine
children.description: 'translating' the output of basic and biomedical research into better diagnostic tools, medicines, medical procedures, policies and advice.

children.name: Molecular Medicine
children.description: The identification of molecular and genetic causes of disease and the development of interventions to correct them.

children.name: Respiratory Medicine
children.description: A medical specialty concerned with diagnosis and treatment of lung disorders and other breathing problems.

children.name: Angiology
children.description: Angiology is the medical specialty which studies the diseases of the circulatory system and of the lymphatic system, i.e., arteries, veins and lymphatic vessels, and its diseases.

children.name: Otolaryngology
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disorders of the ear, nose and throat.

children.name: Systems Medicine
children.description: An interdisciplinary field of study that looks at the dynamic systems of the human body as part of an integrted whole, incoporating biochemical, physiological, and environmental interactions that sustain life.

children.name: Obstetrics
children.description: A medical-surgical specialty dealing with the care of a woman and her offspring during pregnancy, childbirth and the puerperium (the period shortly after birth).

children.name: Pain Medicine
children.description: The prevention of pain and the evaluation, treatment and rehabilitation of persons in pain.

children.name: Medical Informatics
children.description: The application of informatics methods to manage medical information and improve healthcare.

children.name: Medical Biometry
children.description: Medical Biometry is the branch of science that deals with the statistical analysis of numerical data relating to humans, especially concerning genetic relationships or medical conditions.

children.name: Hematology
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the blood and blood-forming organs and the diseases thereof.

children.name: Transfusion Medicine
children.description: Transfusion Medicine is the branch of medicine that is concerned with transfusion of blood and blood components. It encompasses issues of blood donation, immunohematology and other laboratory testing, transfusion practices, patient blood management, therapeutic apheresis, stem cell collections, cellular therapy, and coagulation.

children.name: Pathology
children.description: The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

children.name: Pathobiochemistry
children.description: Pathobiochemistry is an intersiciplinary research area related to both biochemistry and pathology. Research focuses on diseases as a disruption of the ordinary biochemical processes of an organism.

children.name: Traumatology
children.description: The branch of medicine that treats body wounds or shock produced by sudden physical injury, as from violence or accident.

children.name: Health Science
children.description: The sciences concerned with health promotion and maintenance.

children.name: Clinical Immunology
children.description: The medical field that deals with immune diseases, including autoimmune diseases, allergies, rejection of organ transplants and immune deficiency.

children.name: Biomedical Science
children.description: Research concerned with the application of biological and physiological principles to clinical medicine.

children.name: Anatomy
children.description: The form and function of the structures of living organisms.

children.name: Medical Microbiology
children.description: The study of microorganisms with an emphasis on their role in the human disease process.

children.name: Molecular Infection Biology
children.description: Molecular Infection Biology is the branch of molecular biology which applies to infectious agents.

children.name: Medicines Research and Development
children.description: The discovery, development and approval of medicines.

children.name: Drug Discovery
children.description: The discovery and design of drugs or potential drug compounds.

children.name: Medicinal Chemistry
children.description: The design and chemical synthesis of bioactive molecules, for example drugs or potential drug compounds, for medicinal purposes.

children.name: Biotherapeutics
children.description: The process of formulating and administering a pharmaceutical compound to achieve a therapeutic effect.

children.name: Clinical Studies
children.description: Research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects; includes development of new technologies, study of mechanisms of human diseases, therapy, clinical trials, epidemiologic, behavior, and health services research.

children.name: Toxicology
children.description: Toxicology is the branch of pharmacology that deals with the nature and effects and treatments of poisons.

children.name: Toxicogenomics
children.description: Toxicogenomics is a new scientific field that elucidates how the entire genome is involved in biological responses of organisms exposed to environmental toxicants/stressors. Toxicogenomics combines information from studies of genomic-scale mRNA profiling (by microarray analysis), cell-wide or tissue-wide protein profiling (proteomics), genetic susceptibility, and computational models to understand the roles of gene-environment interactions in disease. (from National Center for Toxicogenomics homepage)

children.name: Medical Toxicology
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis, management and prevention of poisoning and other adverse health effects caused by medications, occupational and environmental toxins, and biological agents.

children.name: Drug Repositioning
children.description: Drug repositioning is the deliberate and methodical practice of finding new applications for existing drugs.

children.name: Drug Metabolism
children.description: A series of chemical modifications of a drug compound by enzymatic activity that make the substrate (drug) more water soluble to allow its clearance from the body. Drug metabolism occurs in two phases: Phase I (biotransformation) involves oxidation, hydroxylation reduction, and hydrolysis. Phase II (conjugation) involves synthesis and conjugation.

children.name: Drug Development
children.description: The process of bringing a new drug to market once a lead compounds has been identified through drug discovery.

children.name: Preclinical Studies
children.description: An investigation that tests a drug, procedure or medical treatment in animals to determine any toxic effects before trials can be carried out in humans.

children.name: Immunology
children.description: The study of the immune system and its reaction to pathogens, as well as its malfunctions (autoimmune diseases, allergies, rejection of organ transplants).

children.name: Clinical Immunology
children.description: The medical field that deals with immune diseases, including autoimmune diseases, allergies, rejection of organ transplants and immune deficiency.

children.name: Nutritional Science
children.description: The study of the effects of food components on the metabolism, health, performance and disease resistance of humans and animals.  It also includes the study of human behaviours related to food choices.

children.name: Animal Nutrition
children.description: Animal Nutrition is the science of feeds and their nutrients, their relation to animal health and disease; for providing feeds to animals use.

children.name: Parasitology
children.description: A branch of biology which deals with parasitic organisms with a strong emphasis on their role in disease.

children.name: Neuroscience
children.description: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to the brain and nervous system.

children.name: Cellular Neuroscience
children.description: Cellular Neuroscience is the study of neurons at the cellular level. It includes cell morphology and physiological properties such as membrane trafficking, synthesis and transport of proteins, and synaptic plasticity.

children.name: Neurogenetics
children.description: Neurogenetics studies the role of genetics in the development and function of the nervous system.

children.name: Psychotherapy
children.description: A method of treating disease, esp. psychic disorders, by mental rather than pharmacological means (e.g., suggestion, re-education, hypnotism, and psychoanalysis). (Taber's)

children.name: Neurophysiology
children.description: A branch of neuroscience concerned with the physiology of the nervous system.

children.name: Neurobiology
children.description: The study of the nervous system and brain; its anatomy, physiology and function.

children.name: Developmental Neurobiology
children.description: The branch of neurobiology concerned with the changes that take place in the nervous system between fertilization and maturity.

children.name: Comparative Neurobiology
children.description: Comparative Neurobiology is the study of how nervous systems work by comparing the neurobiology of multiple species.

children.name: Biological Psychology
children.description: Biological psychology is the application of the principles of biology to the study of mental processes and behaviour. For example, it involves the measuring of biological, physiological, or genetic variables in an attempt to relate them to psychological or behavioural variables.

children.name: Cognitive Neuroscience
children.description: Cognitive Neuroscience is the field of study focusing on the neural substrates of mental processes. It is at the intersection of psychology and neuroscience, but also overlaps with physiological psychology, cognitive psychology and neuropsychology. It combines the theories of cognitive psychology and computational modelling with experimental data about the brain.

children.name: Computational Neuroscience
children.description: Computational Neuroscience is the field of study in which mathematical tools and theories are used to investigate brain function. It can also incorporate diverse approaches from electrical engineering, computer science and physics in order to understand how the nervous system processes information.

children.name: Biological Psychiatry
children.description: Biological Psychiatry is the branch of psychiatry concerned with the biological basis for mental disorders, typically using physical methods or medication (as opposed to psychotherapy) as treatment.

children.name: Ophthalmology
children.description: A medical specialty concerned with the structure and function of the eye and the medical and surgical treatment of its defects and diseases.

children.name: Molecular Neuroscience
children.description: Molecular Neuroscience is a branch of neuroscience that examines the biology of the nervous system with molecular biology, molecular genetics, protein chemistry and related methodologies.

children.name: Psychosomatic Medicine
children.description: A branch of medicine concerned with the relationship between emotion and body function.

children.name: Neurology
children.description: A branch of medicine concerned with the development, anatomy, function, and dysfunction of the nervous system.

children.name: Systemic Neuroscience
children.description: Systemic Neuroscience is a subdiscipline of Neuroscience and Systems Biology that studies the structure and function of neural circuits and systems. It encompasses a number of areas of study concerned with how nerve cells behave when connected together to form neural pathways, neural circuits, and larger brain networks.

children.name: Molecular Neurology
children.description: Molecular Neurology is the study of the molecular basis of neurology and neurological disorders.

children.name: Agriculture
children.description: Agriculture is the science, art, or practice of cultivating the soil, producing crops, and raising livestock and in varying degrees the preparation and marketing of the resulting products.

children.name: Farming Systems Research
children.description: Farming System Research is an approach designed to generate relevant technologies for specific clients, most commonly, the resource-limited farm households. It focuses on clients' priority needs and problems, applies an inter-disciplinary systems perspective in diagnosing problems and generating technological solutions, and involve a series of operational activities carried out on farm with farmers. Although descriptions of Farming Systems Research vary, the general consensus is that there are four major activities: diagnosis, planning and priority setting, experimentation and evaluation. The activities incorporated under farming systems research range from computer models simulating small-scale farm systems to integrated rural development strategies, and from complex experiment station trials of cropping systems to simple on-farm testing of technologies. [AgroVoc, AL 14.5.2019]

children.name: Agroecology
children.description: Agroecology is the study of ecological processes applied to agricultural production systems.

children.name: Plant Nutrition
children.description: Plant Nutrition is the science of plant nutrients and their relation to plant health and disease. [AgroVoc, AL 17.6.2019]

children.name: Animal Nutrition
children.description: Animal Nutrition is the science of feeds and their nutrients, their relation to animal health and disease; for providing feeds to animals use.

children.name: Forest Management
children.description: Forest Management is a branch of forestry concerned with overall administrative, economic, legal, and social aspects, as well as scientific and technical aspects, such as silviculture, protection, and forest regulation. This includes management for aesthetics, fish, recreation, urban values, water, wilderness, wildlife, wood products, forest genetic resources, and other forest resource values. Management can be based on conservation, economics, or a mixture of the two.

children.name: Phytomedicine
children.description: Phytomedicine is a plant-based traditional medicinal practice that uses various plant materials in preventive and therapeutic processes (Wallis, 2005; Ali, 2008). [ScienceDirect https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/nursing-and-health-professions/phytomedicine, AL 6.6.2019]

children.name: Plant Breeding
children.description: Plant Breeding is the research area concerned with raising a certain type of plant by crossing one variety with another to produce a new variety where the desired characteristics are strongest. [GEMET https://www.eionet.europa.eu/gemet/en/concept/6298, AL 12.6.2019]

children.name: Food Process Engineering
children.description: Food Process Engineering is a field of study focusing on the applications of engineering principles and concepts to food and food processes. The processes include any physical properties and changes to the food product that result in preservation of the food, extending to transportation, product shelf-life, or improvements in the product quality attributes.

children.name: Horticulture
children.description: Horticulture is the research area concerned with the cultivation or management of gardens, including the growing of flowers, fruits, and vegetables. [Adapted from OED, AL 19.6.2019]

children.name: Animal Husbandry
children.description: Animal Husbandry is the branch of agriculture concerned with animals that are raised for meat, fibre, milk, eggs, or other products. It includes day-to-day care, selective breeding and the raising of livestock.

children.name: Animal Breeding
children.description: Animal Breeding is a branch of Agriculture that addresses the controlled improvement of selected characteristics of livestock. [Adapted from AgroVoc and Wikipedia, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_breeding, 1.4.2019]

children.name: Agricultural Engineering
children.description: Agricultural Engineering is a discipline concerned with developing and improving the means for providing food and fiber for mankind's needs.

children.name: Agronomy
children.description: Agronomy is the science of crop production and soil management. [AgroVoc, AL 19.6.2019]

children.name: Soil Science
children.description: Soil Science is the study of the properties, occurrence, and management of soil as a natural resource. Generally it includes the chemistry, microbiology, physics, morphology, and mineralogy of soils, as well as their genesis and classification.

children.name: Plant Cultivation
children.description: Plant Cultivation is the practice of growing and nurturing plants outside of their wild habitat (i.e., in gardens, nurseries, arboreta). [Adapted from https://www.eionet.europa.eu/gemet/en/concept/1899, AL 12.6.2019]

children.name: Agricultural Economics
children.description: Agricultural Economics is an applied social science that deals with the production, distribution, and consumption of agricultural or farming goods and services.

children.name: Food Security
children.description: Food Security is the area of research concerned with physical and economic access, by all people at all times, to the basic food they need.

children.name: Veterinary Medicine
children.description: Topic concerning the branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disease, disorder and injury in animals.

children.name: Clinical Veterinary Medicine
children.description: Clinical Veterinary Medicine deals with the observation, diagnosis and treatment of illness, disease or damage through direct interaction with non-human patients.

children.name: Natural History
children.description: Natural History is a domain of inquiry involving organisms including animals, fungi and plants in their environment; leaning more towards observational than experimental methods of study.

children.name: Paleontology
children.description: Paleontology is the branch of science that deals with extinct and fossil humans, animals, and plants, or more generally with evidence of organic life during the geological past.

children.name: Biology
children.description: The scientific study of living organisms.

children.name: Botany
children.description: Plants, e.g. information on a specific plant genome including molecular sequences, genes and annotation.

children.name: Plant Nutrition
children.description: Plant Nutrition is the science of plant nutrients and their relation to plant health and disease. [AgroVoc, AL 17.6.2019]

children.name: Plant Ecology
children.description: Plant Ecology is a subdiscipline of Ecology which studies the distribution and abundance of plants, the effects of environmental factors upon the abundance of plants, and the interactions among and between plants and other organisms.

children.name: Phytochemistry
children.description: Phytochemistry is the chemistry of plants and plant products.

children.name: Plant Physiology
children.description: Plant Physiology is concerned with the study of the function and chemical reactions within the various organs of plants. [Adapted from GEMET https://www.eionet.europa.eu/gemet/en/concept/6316, AL 12.6.2019]

children.name: Inter-organismic Interactions of Plants
children.description: Inter-organismic Interactions of Plants is a research area concerned with all biochemical, physiological and molecular aspects of plant-plant interactions. [Adapted from https://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?show=aimsScope&journalCode=tjpi20, AL 17.6.2019]

children.name: Plant Anatomy
children.description: An anatomical entity that is or was part of a plant.

children.name: Plant Cell Biology
children.description: Plant Cell Biology is a research area focusing on the how the processes underlying plant cell function and development are regulated.

children.name: Plant Genetics
children.description: Plant Genetics is the scientific study of the hereditary material of plants for purposes such as hybridization, improved food resources and increased production. [GEMET https://www.eionet.europa.eu/gemet/en/concept/6307, AL 12.6.2019]

children.name: Environmental Science
children.description: Environmental Science is a broad interdisciplinary field in which ecologists work with other physical, chemical, and biological researchers to study and seek solutions to environmental problems. Environmental science focuses on the environment and how humans can manage and utilise its resources and the effects our actions have on the environment.

children.name: Anatomy
children.description: The form and function of the structures of living organisms.

children.name: Molecular biology
children.description: The molecular basis of biological activity, particularly the macromolecules (e.g. proteins and nucleic acids) that are essential to life.

children.name: Molecular Infection Biology
children.description: Molecular Infection Biology is the branch of molecular biology which applies to infectious agents.

children.name: Molecular Neuroscience
children.description: Molecular Neuroscience is a branch of neuroscience that examines the biology of the nervous system with molecular biology, molecular genetics, protein chemistry and related methodologies.

children.name: Zoology
children.description: The branch of biology dealing with the study of animals.

children.name: Animal Genetics
children.description: The study of genetic traits in animals.

children.name: Animal Physiology
children.description: Animal Physiology is the study of the normal processes and metabolic functions of animal organisms.

children.name: Entomology
children.description: Entomology; the branch of zoology that studies insects.

children.name: Behavioural Biology
children.description: Behavioural Biology is an interdisciplinary degree and field of science that examines the bidirectional interactions between behaviour and biology. An organismâ€™s genetic, physiological and immunological processes drive behaviour, just as an individual's behaviour will impact its physiological and immunological state.

children.name: Biodiversity
children.description: The degree of variation of life forms within a given ecosystem, biome or an entire planet.

children.name: Evolutionary Biology
children.description: The evolutionary processes, from the genetic to environmental scale, that produced life in all its diversity.

children.name: Taxonomy
children.description: Organism classification, identification and naming.

children.name: Phylogeny
children.description: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms.

children.name: Phylogenetics
children.description: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms from analysis of genetic information (typically gene or protein sequences).

children.name: Phylogenomics
children.description: The integrated study of evolutionary relationships and whole genome data, for example, in the analysis of species trees, horizontal gene transfer and evolutionary reconstruction.

children.name: Phenomics
children.description: Phenomes, or the study of the change in phenotype (the physical and biochemical traits of organisms) in response to genetic and environmental factors.

children.name: Ecosystem Science
children.description: Ecosystem Science is the study of inter-relationships among the living organisms, physical features, bio-chemical processes, natural phenomena, and human activities in ecological communities. [NOAA https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/ecosci.html, AL 16.5.2019]

children.name: Marine Biology
children.description: The study of organisms in the ocean or brackish waters.

children.name: Freshwater Science
children.description: The study of organisms in freshwater ecosystems.

children.name: Cheminformatics
children.description: The application of information technology to chemistry in biological research environment.

children.name: Biochemistry
children.description: Chemical substances and physico-chemical processes and that occur within living organisms.

children.name: Pathobiochemistry
children.description: Pathobiochemistry is an intersiciplinary research area related to both biochemistry and pathology. Research focuses on diseases as a disruption of the ordinary biochemical processes of an organism.

children.name: Phytochemistry
children.description: Phytochemistry is the chemistry of plants and plant products.

children.name: Enzymology
children.description: The branch of biochemistry dealing with the chemical nature and biological activity of enzymes.

children.name: Glycomics
children.description: A study of the complete set of glycans produced in a given cell or organism under specific conditions.

children.name: Bioinformatics
children.description: Bioinformatics derives knowledge from computer analysis of biological data. These can consist of the information stored in the genetic code, but also experimental results from various sources, patient statistics, and scientific literature. Research in bioinformatics includes method development for storage, retrieval, and analysis of the data. Bioinformatics is a rapidly developing branch of biology and is highly interdisciplinary, using techniques and concepts from informatics, statistics, mathematics, chemistry, biochemistry, physics, and linguistics. It has many practical applications in different areas of biology and medicine. (M. Nilges and Jens P. Linge, Unite de Bio-informatique Structurale, Institut Pasteur, Paris)

children.name: Proteogenomics
children.description: A method of study that relates annotated genomic information to global protein expression in order to determine the relationship between genomic sequences and both expressed proteins and predicted peptide sequences; these studies can identify novel coding regions.

children.name: Structural Biology
children.description: The discipline concerned with the three-dimensional configuration of biological molecules and the influence of structure on function.

children.name: Genetics
children.description: The branch of biology that deals with heredity, especially the mechanisms of hereditary transmission and the variation of inherited characteristics among similar or related organisms

children.name: Neurogenetics
children.description: Neurogenetics studies the role of genetics in the development and function of the nervous system.

children.name: Epigenetics
children.description: Epigenetics is the study of the chemical modification of specific genes or gene-associated proteins of an organism. [Encyclopedia Britannica https://www.britannica.com/science/epigenetics, AL 10.06.2019]

children.name: Epigenomics
children.description: The study of the epigenetic modifications of a whole cell, tissue, organism etc.

children.name: Immunogenetics
children.description: A sub-field of genetics that uses both genetic and immunological analyses to study the genetics behind antibody formation and the immune response. (Biotech Life Science Dictionary)

children.name: Phylogenetics
children.description: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms from analysis of genetic information (typically gene or protein sequences).

children.name: Quantitative Genetics
children.description: The genes and genetic mechanisms such as Mendelian inheritance that underly continuous phenotypic traits (such as height or weight).

children.name: Human Genetics
children.description: The study of inheritance in human beings.

children.name: Microbial Genetics
children.description: A branch of genetics concerned with the mechanisms and processes of heredity in microorganisms.

children.name: Molecular Genetics
children.description: The structure and function of genes at a molecular level.

children.name: Transcriptomics
children.description: The analysis of transcriptomes, or a set of all the RNA molecules in a specific cell, tissue etc.

children.name: Metatranscriptomics
children.description: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).

children.name: Population Genetics
children.description: The distribution of allele frequencies in a population of organisms and its change subject to evolutionary processes including natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow.

children.name: Plant Genetics
children.description: Plant Genetics is the scientific study of the hereditary material of plants for purposes such as hybridization, improved food resources and increased production. [GEMET https://www.eionet.europa.eu/gemet/en/concept/6307, AL 12.6.2019]

children.name: Soft Matter Physics
children.description: Soft Matter Physics sits at the interface between chemistry, physics and biology, and includes investigation of the structure, self-assembly, kinetics and properties of liquids, colloids, particles, formulations, gels, foams, sprays, soft solids and interfaces.

children.name: Chemical Biology
children.description: The use of synthetic chemistry to study and manipulate biological systems.

children.name: Biophysics
children.description: Physics as applied to biological problems; an interdisciplinary science that applies theories and methods of the physical sciences to questions of biology.

children.name: Medical Physics
children.description: Medical Physics is the application of physics to healthcare; using physics for patient imaging, measurement and treatment.

children.name: Ecology
children.description: The branch of biology concerned with the relations between organisms and their environment.

children.name: Agroecology
children.description: Agroecology is the study of ecological processes applied to agricultural production systems.

children.name: Plant Ecology
children.description: Plant Ecology is a subdiscipline of Ecology which studies the distribution and abundance of plants, the effects of environmental factors upon the abundance of plants, and the interactions among and between plants and other organisms.

children.name: Microbial Ecology
children.description: The ecology of microorganisms including their relationship with one another and their environment.

children.name: Metaproteomics
children.description: Metaproteomics refers to the large-scale characterization of the entire protein complement of environmental or clinical samples at a given point in time. The method indiscriminately identifies proteins from the microbiota and the host/environments (metagenome). Computational analyses afford assignments of these proteins to their biological origins. It is often performed using liquid-chromatography-based separation coupled to mass spectrometry for peptide identification.

children.name: Metagenomics
children.description: The study of genetic material recovered from environmental samples, and associated environmental data.

children.name: Metatranscriptomics
children.description: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).

children.name: Metataxonomics
children.description: Metataxonomics is the high-throughput process used to characterize the entire microbiota and create a metataxonomic tree, which shows the relationships between all sequences obtained. While viruses are an integral part of the microbiota, no universal viral marker genes are available to perform such taxonomic assignments.

children.name: Biodiversity
children.description: The degree of variation of life forms within a given ecosystem, biome or an entire planet.

children.name: Biotechnology
children.description: The exploitation of biological process, structure and function for industrial purposes, for example the genetic manipulation of microorganisms for the antibody production.

children.name: Applied Microbiology
children.description: Applied Microbiology is a scientific discipline that deals with the application of microorganisms and the knowledge about them. Applications include biotechnology, agriculture, medicine, food microbiology and bioremediation.

children.name: Biomaterials
children.description: Any matter, surface or construct that interacts with a biological system.

children.name: Medical Biotechnology
children.description: Biotechnology applied to the medical sciences and the development of medicines.

children.name: Bioengineering
children.description: Bioengineering integrates physical, chemical, or mathematical sciences and engineering principles for treatment and for the study of biology, medicine, behavior, or health.

children.name: Synthetic Biology
children.description: Synthetic Biology is a field of biological research combining engineering in the formulation, design, and building (synthesis) of novel biological structures, functions, and systems.

children.name: Biomimetic Chemistry
children.description: Biomimetic Chemistry deals with chemical systems that can simulate biological phenomena, particularly catalysis and specificity.

children.name: Computational Biology
children.description: The development and application of theory, analytical methods, mathematical models and computational simulation of biological systems.

children.name: Functional Genomics
children.description: The study of gene or protein functions and their interactions in totality in a given organism, tissue, cell etc.

children.name: Phylogeny
children.description: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms.

children.name: Phylogenetics
children.description: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms from analysis of genetic information (typically gene or protein sequences).

children.name: Phylogenomics
children.description: The integrated study of evolutionary relationships and whole genome data, for example, in the analysis of species trees, horizontal gene transfer and evolutionary reconstruction.

children.name: Molecular Dynamics
children.description: The science of simulating the motions of a system of particles. (Karplus and Petsko)

children.name: Molecular Genetics
children.description: The structure and function of genes at a molecular level.

children.name: Transcriptomics
children.description: The analysis of transcriptomes, or a set of all the RNA molecules in a specific cell, tissue etc.

children.name: Metatranscriptomics
children.description: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).

children.name: Developmental Biology
children.description: The study of how a multicellular organism develops from its early immature forms (e.g., zygote, larva, embryo) into an adult.

children.name: Developmental Psychology
children.description: The study of the psychological and behavioral changes that occur in an organism between birth and old age.

children.name: Embryology
children.description: The development of organisms between the one-cell stage (typically the zygote) and the end of the embryonic stage.

children.name: Physiology
children.description: The functions of living organisms and their constituent parts.

children.name: Neurophysiology
children.description: A branch of neuroscience concerned with the physiology of the nervous system.

children.name: Animal Physiology
children.description: Animal Physiology is the study of the normal processes and metabolic functions of animal organisms.

children.name: Microbial Physiology
children.description: The metabolism of microbial life forms.

children.name: Electrophysiology
children.description: That branch of physiology that is concerned with the electric phenomena associated with living bodies and involved in their functional activity.

children.name: Cell Biology
children.description: The study of the internal workings of cells at the microscopic and molecular level.

children.name: Plant Cell Biology
children.description: Plant Cell Biology is a research area focusing on the how the processes underlying plant cell function and development are regulated.

children.name: Biomedical Science
children.description: Research concerned with the application of biological and physiological principles to clinical medicine.

children.name: Anatomy
children.description: The form and function of the structures of living organisms.

children.name: Medical Microbiology
children.description: The study of microorganisms with an emphasis on their role in the human disease process.

children.name: Molecular Infection Biology
children.description: Molecular Infection Biology is the branch of molecular biology which applies to infectious agents.

children.name: Medicines Research and Development
children.description: The discovery, development and approval of medicines.

children.name: Drug Discovery
children.description: The discovery and design of drugs or potential drug compounds.

children.name: Medicinal Chemistry
children.description: The design and chemical synthesis of bioactive molecules, for example drugs or potential drug compounds, for medicinal purposes.

children.name: Biotherapeutics
children.description: The process of formulating and administering a pharmaceutical compound to achieve a therapeutic effect.

children.name: Clinical Studies
children.description: Research conducted with human subjects or on material of human origin in which an investigator directly interacts with human subjects; includes development of new technologies, study of mechanisms of human diseases, therapy, clinical trials, epidemiologic, behavior, and health services research.

children.name: Toxicology
children.description: Toxicology is the branch of pharmacology that deals with the nature and effects and treatments of poisons.

children.name: Toxicogenomics
children.description: Toxicogenomics is a new scientific field that elucidates how the entire genome is involved in biological responses of organisms exposed to environmental toxicants/stressors. Toxicogenomics combines information from studies of genomic-scale mRNA profiling (by microarray analysis), cell-wide or tissue-wide protein profiling (proteomics), genetic susceptibility, and computational models to understand the roles of gene-environment interactions in disease. (from National Center for Toxicogenomics homepage)

children.name: Medical Toxicology
children.description: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis, management and prevention of poisoning and other adverse health effects caused by medications, occupational and environmental toxins, and biological agents.

children.name: Drug Repositioning
children.description: Drug repositioning is the deliberate and methodical practice of finding new applications for existing drugs.

children.name: Drug Metabolism
children.description: A series of chemical modifications of a drug compound by enzymatic activity that make the substrate (drug) more water soluble to allow its clearance from the body. Drug metabolism occurs in two phases: Phase I (biotransformation) involves oxidation, hydroxylation reduction, and hydrolysis. Phase II (conjugation) involves synthesis and conjugation.

children.name: Drug Development
children.description: The process of bringing a new drug to market once a lead compounds has been identified through drug discovery.

children.name: Preclinical Studies
children.description: An investigation that tests a drug, procedure or medical treatment in animals to determine any toxic effects before trials can be carried out in humans.

children.name: Immunology
children.description: The study of the immune system and its reaction to pathogens, as well as its malfunctions (autoimmune diseases, allergies, rejection of organ transplants).

children.name: Clinical Immunology
children.description: The medical field that deals with immune diseases, including autoimmune diseases, allergies, rejection of organ transplants and immune deficiency.

children.name: Nutritional Science
children.description: The study of the effects of food components on the metabolism, health, performance and disease resistance of humans and animals.  It also includes the study of human behaviours related to food choices.

children.name: Animal Nutrition
children.description: Animal Nutrition is the science of feeds and their nutrients, their relation to animal health and disease; for providing feeds to animals use.

children.name: Parasitology
children.description: A branch of biology which deals with parasitic organisms with a strong emphasis on their role in disease.

children.name: Neuroscience
children.description: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to the brain and nervous system.

children.name: Cellular Neuroscience
children.description: Cellular Neuroscience is the study of neurons at the cellular level. It includes cell morphology and physiological properties such as membrane trafficking, synthesis and transport of proteins, and synaptic plasticity.

children.name: Neurogenetics
children.description: Neurogenetics studies the role of genetics in the development and function of the nervous system.

children.name: Psychotherapy
children.description: A method of treating disease, esp. psychic disorders, by mental rather than pharmacological means (e.g., suggestion, re-education, hypnotism, and psychoanalysis). (Taber's)

children.name: Neurophysiology
children.description: A branch of neuroscience concerned with the physiology of the nervous system.

children.name: Neurobiology
children.description: The study of the nervous system and brain; its anatomy, physiology and function.

children.name: Developmental Neurobiology
children.description: The branch of neurobiology concerned with the changes that take place in the nervous system between fertilization and maturity.

children.name: Comparative Neurobiology
children.description: Comparative Neurobiology is the study of how nervous systems work by comparing the neurobiology of multiple species.

children.name: Biological Psychology
children.description: Biological psychology is the application of the principles of biology to the study of mental processes and behaviour. For example, it involves the measuring of biological, physiological, or genetic variables in an attempt to relate them to psychological or behavioural variables.

children.name: Cognitive Neuroscience
children.description: Cognitive Neuroscience is the field of study focusing on the neural substrates of mental processes. It is at the intersection of psychology and neuroscience, but also overlaps with physiological psychology, cognitive psychology and neuropsychology. It combines the theories of cognitive psychology and computational modelling with experimental data about the brain.

children.name: Computational Neuroscience
children.description: Computational Neuroscience is the field of study in which mathematical tools and theories are used to investigate brain function. It can also incorporate diverse approaches from electrical engineering, computer science and physics in order to understand how the nervous system processes information.

children.name: Biological Psychiatry
children.description: Biological Psychiatry is the branch of psychiatry concerned with the biological basis for mental disorders, typically using physical methods or medication (as opposed to psychotherapy) as treatment.

children.name: Ophthalmology
children.description: A medical specialty concerned with the structure and function of the eye and the medical and surgical treatment of its defects and diseases.

children.name: Molecular Neuroscience
children.description: Molecular Neuroscience is a branch of neuroscience that examines the biology of the nervous system with molecular biology, molecular genetics, protein chemistry and related methodologies.

children.name: Psychosomatic Medicine
children.description: A branch of medicine concerned with the relationship between emotion and body function.

children.name: Neurology
children.description: A branch of medicine concerned with the development, anatomy, function, and dysfunction of the nervous system.

children.name: Systemic Neuroscience
children.description: Systemic Neuroscience is a subdiscipline of Neuroscience and Systems Biology that studies the structure and function of neural circuits and systems. It encompasses a number of areas of study concerned with how nerve cells behave when connected together to form neural pathways, neural circuits, and larger brain networks.

children.name: Molecular Neurology
children.description: Molecular Neurology is the study of the molecular basis of neurology and neurological disorders.

children.name: Microbiology
children.description: The science that deals with the study of microorganisms, including algae, archaea, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, and viruses.

children.name: Soil Science
children.description: Soil Science is the study of the properties, occurrence, and management of soil as a natural resource. Generally it includes the chemistry, microbiology, physics, morphology, and mineralogy of soils, as well as their genesis and classification.

children.name: Microbial Ecology
children.description: The ecology of microorganisms including their relationship with one another and their environment.

children.name: Metaproteomics
children.description: Metaproteomics refers to the large-scale characterization of the entire protein complement of environmental or clinical samples at a given point in time. The method indiscriminately identifies proteins from the microbiota and the host/environments (metagenome). Computational analyses afford assignments of these proteins to their biological origins. It is often performed using liquid-chromatography-based separation coupled to mass spectrometry for peptide identification.

children.name: Metagenomics
children.description: The study of genetic material recovered from environmental samples, and associated environmental data.

children.name: Metatranscriptomics
children.description: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).

children.name: Metataxonomics
children.description: Metataxonomics is the high-throughput process used to characterize the entire microbiota and create a metataxonomic tree, which shows the relationships between all sequences obtained. While viruses are an integral part of the microbiota, no universal viral marker genes are available to perform such taxonomic assignments.

children.name: Medical Microbiology
children.description: The study of microorganisms with an emphasis on their role in the human disease process.

children.name: Applied Microbiology
children.description: Applied Microbiology is a scientific discipline that deals with the application of microorganisms and the knowledge about them. Applications include biotechnology, agriculture, medicine, food microbiology and bioremediation.

children.name: Molecular Infection Biology
children.description: Molecular Infection Biology is the branch of molecular biology which applies to infectious agents.

children.name: Microbial Physiology
children.description: The metabolism of microbial life forms.

children.name: Microbial Genetics
children.description: A branch of genetics concerned with the mechanisms and processes of heredity in microorganisms.

children.name: Virology
children.description: Study of viruses, e.g. sequence and structural data, interactions of viral proteins, or a viral genome including molecular sequences, genes and annotation.

children.name: Medical Virology
children.description: Medical Virology is the study of the diagnosis and management of infectious diseases from a clinical and laboratory perspective, with particular interest in infection control, medical microbiology and public health.

children.name: Molecular Microbiology
children.description: Molecular Microbiology is the branch of microbiology devoted to the study of the molecular basis of the physiological processes that occur in microorganisms.

children.name: Radiobiology
children.description: The study of the mechanisms and biological effects of ionizing radiation, including repair processes.

children.name: Radiation Oncology
children.description: Radiation Oncology is the study of the effects of ionizing radiation for treatment of tumors.

children.name: Human Biology
children.description: Interdisciplinary studies involving biology, anthropology, nutrition, and medicine with a focus on humans.

children.name: Omics
children.description: The collective characterisation and quantification of pools of biological molecules that translate into the structure, function, and dynamics of an organism or organisms.

children.name: Genomics
children.description: The study of comprehensive sets of genes via high throughput methods.

children.name: Functional Genomics
children.description: The study of gene or protein functions and their interactions in totality in a given organism, tissue, cell etc.

children.name: Toxicogenomics
children.description: Toxicogenomics is a new scientific field that elucidates how the entire genome is involved in biological responses of organisms exposed to environmental toxicants/stressors. Toxicogenomics combines information from studies of genomic-scale mRNA profiling (by microarray analysis), cell-wide or tissue-wide protein profiling (proteomics), genetic susceptibility, and computational models to understand the roles of gene-environment interactions in disease. (from National Center for Toxicogenomics homepage)

children.name: Epigenomics
children.description: The study of the epigenetic modifications of a whole cell, tissue, organism etc.

children.name: Metagenomics
children.description: The study of genetic material recovered from environmental samples, and associated environmental data.

children.name: Proteogenomics
children.description: A method of study that relates annotated genomic information to global protein expression in order to determine the relationship between genomic sequences and both expressed proteins and predicted peptide sequences; these studies can identify novel coding regions.

children.name: Phylogenomics
children.description: The integrated study of evolutionary relationships and whole genome data, for example, in the analysis of species trees, horizontal gene transfer and evolutionary reconstruction.

children.name: Pharmacogenomics
children.description: The influence of genotype on drug response, for example by correlating gene expression or single-nucleotide polymorphisms with drug efficacy or toxicity.

children.name: Transcriptomics
children.description: The analysis of transcriptomes, or a set of all the RNA molecules in a specific cell, tissue etc.

children.name: Metatranscriptomics
children.description: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).

children.name: Comparative Genomics
children.description: The study (typically comparison) of the sequence, structure or function of multiple genomes.

children.name: Proteomics
children.description: The global analysis of cellular proteins. Proteomics uses a combination of sophisticated techniques including two-dimensional (2D) gel electrophoresis, image analysis, mass spectrometry, amino acid sequencing, and bio-informatics to resolve comprehensively, to quantify, and to characterize proteins. The application of proteomics provides major opportunities to elucidate disease mechanisms and to identify new diagnostic markers and therapeutic targets.

children.name: Metaproteomics
children.description: Metaproteomics refers to the large-scale characterization of the entire protein complement of environmental or clinical samples at a given point in time. The method indiscriminately identifies proteins from the microbiota and the host/environments (metagenome). Computational analyses afford assignments of these proteins to their biological origins. It is often performed using liquid-chromatography-based separation coupled to mass spectrometry for peptide identification.

children.name: Glycomics
children.description: A study of the complete set of glycans produced in a given cell or organism under specific conditions.

children.name: Metabolomics
children.description: The systematic study of metabolites, the chemical processes they are involved, and the chemical fingerprints of specific cellular processes in a whole cell, tissue, organ or organism.

children.name: Phenomics
children.description: Phenomes, or the study of the change in phenotype (the physical and biochemical traits of organisms) in response to genetic and environmental factors.

children.name: Systems Biology
children.description: The holistic modelling and analysis of complex biological systems and the interactions therein.

children.name: Systemic Neuroscience
children.description: Systemic Neuroscience is a subdiscipline of Neuroscience and Systems Biology that studies the structure and function of neural circuits and systems. It encompasses a number of areas of study concerned with how nerve cells behave when connected together to form neural pathways, neural circuits, and larger brain networks.

children.name: Physics
children.description: The study of matter, space and time, and related concepts such as energy and force.

children.name: Atomic, Molecular, Optical and Plasma Physics
children.description: Atomic, Molecular, Optical and Plasma Physics (AMOP) is the study of matter-matter and light-matter interactions; at the scale of one or a few atoms and energy scales around several electron volts.

children.name: Acoustics
children.description: Acoustics is the branch of physics concerned with the properties and phenomena of sound, sometimes esp. in relation to hearing or speech.

children.name: Polymer Physics
children.description: Polymer Physics is the field of physics that studies polymers, their fluctuations, mechanical properties, as well as the kinetics of reactions involving degradation and polymerisation of polymers and monomers respectively.

children.name: Nanotechnology
children.description: A multidisciplinary field that strives to comprehend the interactions of cellular components, molecular components and engineered materials at the nanoscale (i.e., less than 100 nanometers). This discipline focuses on the understanding and control of matter at the nanoscale, wherein unique phenomena enable novel applications.

children.name: Thermodynamics
children.description: The branch of physics concerned with the conversion of different forms of energy.

children.name: Electromagnetism
children.description: Electromagnetism is a branch of physics involving the study of the electromagnetic force, a type of physical interaction that occurs between electrically charged particles.

children.name: Building Engineering Physics
children.description: Building Engineering Physics investigates the areas of natural science that relate to the energy performance of buildings and their indoor and outdoor environments. The understanding and application of Building Engineering Physics allows us to design and construct high performance buildings which are comfortable and functional, yet use natural resources efficiently and minimise the environmental impacts of their construction and operation. It is related to Architecture, Structural Engineering and Building Services Engineering.

children.name: Soft Matter Physics
children.description: Soft Matter Physics sits at the interface between chemistry, physics and biology, and includes investigation of the structure, self-assembly, kinetics and properties of liquids, colloids, particles, formulations, gels, foams, sprays, soft solids and interfaces.

children.name: Computational Neuroscience
children.description: Computational Neuroscience is the field of study in which mathematical tools and theories are used to investigate brain function. It can also incorporate diverse approaches from electrical engineering, computer science and physics in order to understand how the nervous system processes information.

children.name: Meteorology
children.description: Meteorology is the branch of science that deals with atmospheric phenomena and processes, especially with a view to forecasting the weather.

children.name: Biophysics
children.description: Physics as applied to biological problems; an interdisciplinary science that applies theories and methods of the physical sciences to questions of biology.

children.name: Medical Physics
children.description: Medical Physics is the application of physics to healthcare; using physics for patient imaging, measurement and treatment.

children.name: Astrophysics and Astronomy
children.description: Astronomy and astrophysics are the study of objects and phenomena that are found beyond our solar system. This combines theoretical simulations and observation with both terrestrial and space-craft-borne instruments of the electromagnetic radiation and high-energy particles emitted by celestial bodies.

children.name: Cosmology
children.description: Cosmology is a branch of astronomy concerned with the studies of the origin and evolution of the universe, from the Big Bang to today and on into the future.

children.name: Selenography
children.description: Selenography is the study of the surface and physical features of the Moon.

children.name: Nonlinear Dynamics
children.description: Nonlinear Dynamics is the branch of Physics that studies systems governed by equations more complex than the linear, aX+b form. Nonlinear systems, such as the weather or neurons, often appear chaotic, unpredictable or counterintuitive, and yet their behaviour is not random.

children.name: Condensed Matter Physics
children.description: Condensed Matter Physics is the field of physics that deals with the macroscopic and microscopic physical properties of matter. In particular it is concerned with the "condensed" phases that appear whenever the number of constituents in a system is extremely large and the interactions between the constituents are strong.

children.name: Experimental Condensed Matter Physics
children.description: Experimental Condensed Matter Physics involves the use of experimental probes to try to discover new properties of materials. Such probes include effects of electric and magnetic fields, measuring response functions, transport properties and thermometry.

children.name: Theoretical Condensed Matter Physics
children.description: Theoretical Condensed Matter Physics involves the use of theoretical models to understand properties of states of matter. These include models to study the electronic properties of solids and the physics of phase transitions. Modern theoretical studies involve the use of numerical computation of electronic structure and mathematical tools to understand phenomena such as high-temperature superconductivity, topological phases, and gauge symmetries.

children.name: Particles, Nuclei and Fields
children.description: Particles, Nuclei and Fields are interlinked areas of study within Physics. Particle physics is a research area concerned with the nature of the particles that constitute matter and radiation. Atomic nuclei, together with their constituents and interactions are studied within Nuclear Physics. Fields, in physics, are regions in which each point is affected by a force.

children.name: Mechanics
children.description: Its fundamental principle is that any physical system can be decomposed into a collection of simple independent local elements each of which interacts only with its immediate neighbors.  In classical mechanics a complete description of any physical system is supposed to be specified by giving the values of the various fields (e.g., the electric field, the magnetic field, etc.) at each of the relevant spacetime points.

children.name: Applied Mechanics
children.description: Applied Mechanics is the practical application of mechanics and bridges the gap between physical theory and its application to technology. It is used in many fields of engineering, especially Mechanical Engineering and Civil Engineering.

children.name: Fluid Mechanics
children.description: Fluid Mechanics the branch of mechanics dealing with the flow of liquids and gases and the way they respond to and exert forces.

children.name: Statistical Physics
children.description: Statistical Physics is a branch of physics that uses probability theory and statistics to solve physical problems that usually involve systems composed of a large number of units. Its main purpose is to study the properties of a system from the statistical behaviour of its components.

children.name: Chemistry
children.description: The science of the composition, structure, properties, and reactions of matter, especially of atomic and molecular systems.

children.name: Geochemistry
children.description: Geochemistry is defined as the study of the processes that control the abundance, composition, and distribution of chemical compounds and isotopes in geologic environments. [Adapted from https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/geochemistry and https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-12-803350-0.00001-5, AL 2.4.2019]

children.name: Drug Discovery
children.description: The discovery and design of drugs or potential drug compounds.

children.name: Medicinal Chemistry
